reviews.review_title: The Color Purple, is abput a young black woman who has been forced to grow up
reviews.content: The Color Purple, is a first-person point of view novel written by Alice Walker. The story in this novel is told from the perspective of one of the main characters, Celie Johnson. In the book, Celie tells us about her life and the challenges she's facing through a series of letters. Celie's letters are addressed to mostly to God in the beginning of the novel and as the journey goes on Celie starts to send some to her sister Nettie whom she was forced to separate from by her husband, Mr_.Then towards the end of the novel, letters are now being written by Nettie to Celie, this is a huge change in the novel because we (the audience) are being told what's going on from a different character in a whole new place. reviews.review_title: The Color Purple is a Film/Novel based on a Young African American woman living in the South
reviews.content: The Color Purple is a novel written by Alice Walker and a film directed by Steven Spielberg based on a young African American woman living in the south during the 1900's named Celie Johnson. Both the novel in the film are told from first-person point of view of Celie herself. The first time we are introduced to Celie in both the novel and the film she is 14 years old and pregnant for the second time with her fathers child. We then stay with Celie for the next 30 years of her life, after having her children taken away from her and is forced into a marriage with a man named Albert who isn't interested in Celie at all but is instead interested in Celie's younger sister Nettie. Celie does all she can to protect her sister from Albert but knows that it won't last for long and so her and Nettie prepare for the worst. Albert makes an attempt to have sex with Nettie in which Nettie resists and fights back, Albert then kicks Nettie off his land and keeps Celie. As time pasts Celie looks forward to letters that her sister Nettie promised to write, just to know that she's alive and well but for some odd reason she hasn't received any. As time goes on Shug Avery, a juke-joint singer whom Albert has an attraction to comes along and unexpectedly grows a connection with Celie. Shug and Celie then discover that Nettie, Celie's sister has been writing letters to Celie ever since she left but Albert, also known as Mr._ has been keeping them from Celie. This is where the film and the novel have their differences, in my opinion the novel gives a deeper insight when it talks about Nettie's experience in Africa as opposed to Celie's experience in America. The Color Purple outlines the life, marriage, friendships and family of Celie Johnson played by Whoopi Goldberg an African American women at the turn of the nineteenth century in the southern United States. Celie is essentially given to her husband she refers to as "Mister" or Albert Johnson. Albert is in need of a women to care for his children as he is widowed. Celie has great difficulties in life and relationships with the exception of her sister Nettie played by Akosua Busia. Celie evolves greatly within the film and develops strong relationships with other women in her life as she longs for her sister. Celie is determined to survive this life and frequently prays to God for help and salvation.Celie feels alone in her life with little enjoyment. Celie befriends her husband's mistress Shug Avery played by Margaret Avery and relies on her immensely to get through life with a husband she despises. Celie's step-son Harpo played by Willard Pugh marries Sophia played by Oprah Winfrey- Celie is ill prepared to give marital advice to Sophia as Celie only knows violence in her relationship. Celie silently observes her family around her and as she narrates the film allows movie goers know her thoughts. The Color Purple is racially charged as Sophia is punished for defending herself to a white man. Another movie that a deals with the injustice of racism is 42 a movie about Jackie Robinson. Different scenarios yet two people that overcame racism in pursuit to find happiness. The determination of the female characters- Celie, Nettie, Sophia and Shug to create a bond and a family in a time that was difficult for women and African Americans. The director used angles to zoom into times when Celie was so angry at Mister has she contemplated revenge on him. Along with the sound of sharpening the razor to shave Mister. Celie uses voice over narration during the film as her feelings and thoughts are not allowed to known to anyone but herself. This is impactful to the theme as Celie struggles to be a person in this film as she feels worthless and is conditioned not to speak for herself. The film is thought provoking and can even spark anger at the great injustices that take place throughout the film. Ultimately admiration arises for Celie as she develops as a person and friend all the while her prayers are answered.

reviews.review_title: Not as great as the novel, but a powerful and important story
reviews.content: Far from reaching the level of excellence of Alice Walker's original novel, the movie is still a good one, with great and heart-warming performances from Whoopi Goldberg, Oprah Winfrey and Margaret Avery. When the movie was released in 1985, it was a very unusual thing with an all African-American cast and a story devoted completely to the lives of non-Caucasians in the US. "The Color Purple" is still in many ways a milestone and movie that deserves being watched.

I saw this film the year it was released. A truly powerful film with such a great story to tell. The challenge of being a woman & African American, living in a time where slavery remained a distant memory & where woman could be kept under control so easily. The unfolding of power and the challenges along the way. The character played by Oprah showing only too clearly how black people had to remember their place. The importance of music & food & culture to hold people together through challenges. When I watched the film again last night, I could not remember when I had seen it last. Certainly more than 20 years ago. Still brilliant. Still with powerful messages for all. And the final message remains that it is never to late to change, to claim what is yours or to act with integrity.

The Color Purple is one of Spielberg's best films.  How amazing to see this movie from the same director of Return of the Jedi  and Indiana Jones. He proves that he can actually make movies that matter, though he could conceivably have done a better job representing Alice Walker's masterpiece. Still, one has to question whether any white male could have done a better job telling a black woman's story.The story is a harshly beautiful account of the inner strength and spirit of a woman.  Celie leads a rough life of drudgery, undervalue, and abuse until her husband's lover, Shug, shows her the way to love and to God.  The two women share a poignant romance in the novel that is downplayed in the film, yet still holds much meaning.  Instead of the passion felt in the novel, the movie transforms the relationship into more of an intellectual and spiritual journey.  The two women unite against their struggles, ask questions, and find the answers, learn to love, and learn to cope.  Shug gently teaches Celie about life's truths, and shows her `the color purple,' tangible evidence of God.  Most importantly, though Shug teaches Celie to love herself, transforming her from a downtrodden workhorse to a self-sufficient, self-supporting, strong woman.Though the film stays somewhat true to the themes of the book, it does downplay the feminist undertones somewhat.  Spielberg perhaps makes Celie's husband into a more believable person, and I certainly felt sympathy for him and saw where he was coming from, but it was sympathy that shouldn't have been there.  The movie provided the men with excuses to treat the women the way they did-excuses that were not given to them in the novel.  Spielberg undermines the destructive role of the men in the film, and in so doing, fails to maintain the feminist mood.  The focus changes more from gender, the main focus of the book, to color in the movie.Still, overall, Spielberg surprised me with a wonderful film.  The cinematography was beautiful, and the acting was fabulous.  Whoopi Goldberg performed better than I've ever seen her, Danny Glover was incredible, and Oprah Winfrey was superb.  I was able to completely see from each character's perspective better than in the novel.  I wish I had been able to see the movie in 1985, when my perception of the actors had not yet been so pronounced.  Seeing it now, when each has led a distinguished career, I did find it a little bit more difficult to separate the actors from their characters.  This was definitely a new picture of Goldberg for me, but she did an excellent job.  In spite of my preconceptions, I loved the film.I would give this movie a nine out of ten.  I definitely recommend this movie, but watch it with a box of tissues, and nothing but waterproof mascara.  No one can come way unchanged from such a touching, moving, and beautiful portrayal of one woman's resiliency, courage, and hope.  It's a classic.
Always good. The story and acting proves timeless.

This film will always be a classic. However it suffers at the hands of 'the Spielberg effect'.Character development - there are inconsistencies in the character arc of Glover's Albert; one moment the menacing bully and the next comically bumbling and hapless. Some of the more slapstick comedy moments shoehorned in are out of place with the somber subject matter and is jarring. Celie's own character development is also inconsistent, afraid to speak around Albert most of the time but suddenly happy to sit smugly watching him fumbling in the kitchen and hurting himself (in real life he would almost certainly have taken out his frustration on her and she would at least try and stay out of his way).The soundtrack is sweeping and beautiful, but overly sentimental, almost cheesy. The jazz works well.This film takes a gritty subject matter and makes it all glossy and pretty.That being said it is highly enjoyable and well acted. I've not read the book so can't comment on that but it feels like fiction to me.
